Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Arraignment/Detention as to Billy Villanueva-Carrasquillo (74) Count 1,2 held on 7/31/2015. Present: AUSA Victor Acevedo and defense counsel Mariela Maestre. Defendant assisted by Court Interpreter. Defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings. He waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all applicable counts. The government has seven days to produce discovery, and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Jose A. Fuste, US District Judge for trial setting. As to bail, Government's proffer heard and requests detention; defendant, though only charged as a runner, has a criminal record and Government has evidence that identifies him as an armed enforcer as well. Defense argues that the defendant only has one conviction, was living and working in the Continental U.S. and he voluntarily surrendered. After hearing the parties, the Court sets bail at $10,000 cash or secured with real estate property, defendant to remain in home detention w/EMD and other standard conditions of release apply. Order of release will be issued once the secured amount is posted and the landline is installed. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 9:00 a.m. Hearing held at 9:25 a.m. Hearing ended at 9:32 a.m. Interpreter Edna Brayfield. (sr) (Entered: 07/31/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Arraignment/Detention as to Emanuel Zabala-Perez (24) Count 1,2,3,6,7 held on 8/3/2015. Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo and Mr. Jose Aguayo. Defendant was present and under custody. He was found competent at this time to understand the proceedings. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Fuste for scheduling. As to bail, Mr. Aguayo offered bail conditions. AUSA Acevedo opposed bail and proffered evidence against defendant. After hearing the arguments from the parties, the Court ordered defendant detained without bail. Order to issue. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Bail Hearing as to Edgar Gonzalez-Rivera (34) held on 8/3/2015. Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo and Mr. Alex Rosa-Ambert. Defendant was present and under custody. Amended pretrial report was received and examined by the parties. Mr. Rosa- Ambert addressed the Court offering bail conditions and explaining that the state cases are relevant conduct to this indictment, and that defendant's wife did not want to pursue the other case. AUSA Acevedo opposed bail and made a proffer as to the evidence as to this defendant. Sidebar held. After hearing the arguments from the parties, the Court ruled that the presumption had not been rebutted and ordered defendant detained without bail. Order to issue. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 02:00.Hearing held at 02:31.Hearing ended at 02:41.Interpreter -Sonia Crescioni. (yr) (Entered: 08/05/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance, Arraignment/Detention Hearing as to Arnaldo Alicea-Colon (35) held on 8/3/2015. Present: AUSA Victor Acevedo, Atty. Edwin Leon, PO Edwin Bravo. Defendant was provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and his rights. Also, defendant was advised of the applicable minimum and maximum statutory penalties that he is exposed to if convicted of the charges in the indictment. As to Arraignment, defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings. He waived the reading of the indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to counts 1,2. Case referred to Judge Fuste for further proceedings. As to bail, defense counsel requested bail. The government did not oppose. The Court adopted the conditions of release imposed in the Middle District of Florida but modified the bail amount: $40,000.00 cash or secured, to be posted w/in 10 days. Defendant shall reside in PR at his parents' residence, until the secured amount of the bail is posted. Thereafter, defendant shall reside in the MDF. Travel restricted between Florida and PR and shall  notify in advance the USPO of any travel arrangements. Defendant shall not enter any of the areas covered by the indictment. If drug testing yields positive, then drug testing and treatment will be imposed, plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing held at 03:22. Hearing ended at 03:54. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (ar) (Entered: 08/07/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Initial Appearance as to Hector J. Cruz-Vargas (99) held on 8/12/2015. Defense counsel Francisco Acevedo-Padilla was present. Defendant was interviewed by the Probation Officer and was brought before the Magistrate Judge, was advised of rights, was provided with copy of the indictment and was advised of the applicable minimum and maximum statutory penalties that he is exposed to if convicted of the charges in the Indictment. Defendant hired private counsel. Defendant was committed. Defense counsel informed that he represents another co-defendant and AUSA Victor Acevedo was informed of the particular situation. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Detention Hearings as to Hector J. Cruz-Vargas (99) Count 1,2,3 held on 8/17/2015. AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Juan R. Acevedo (substituting for Francisco Acevedo) were present. The Court inquired defendant if he had any objection of being representing by counsel Acevedo-Cruz instead of retained counsel Acevedo- Padilla. Defendant had no objection to the same. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. During the colloquy, the Court asked defendant if he understood what he was being charged and the maximum penalties, for defendant answered in the affirmative. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case 1s referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As to Detention, the Government had no objection to bail. Defense counsel moved for bond. After listening to the parties, the Court set bond as to Hector J. Cruz-Vargas (99) in the amount of $5,000 of which $2,500 is cash or secured and $2,500 is unsecured. Standard release conditions, third party custodian of wife or father to be qualified, reside with third party custodian, shall not enter areas mentioned in the indictment, employment, study, curfew, drug testing and treatment are all imposed. (Court Reporter DCR/bg.) Hearing set for 11:00. Hearing held at 11:21. Hearing ended at 11:35. Interpreter Enith Valdes. (br) (Entered: 08/20/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment/Detention as to Jesus De Jesus-Colon (31) Counts 1,2,3 held on 9/10/2015. Present: AUSA Victor Hernandez, Atty. Enrique Velez and PO Carolina Aparicio. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Fuste for further proceedings. As to detention, defense counsel had no evidence to rebut the recommendation of the pretrial report, but reserved the right to request a reopening of the bail hearing. The Court ordered defendant detained on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Motion Hearing as to Walter D. Muller-Colon (63) held on 11/20/2015 re 529 Emergency MOTION for Reconsideration re 174 Order of Detention Emergency MOTION for Medical Exam filed by Walter D. Muller-Colon. Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez-Rocafort and Mr. Ramon Garay. Defendant was present and under custody. Mr. Garay addressed the Court stating that defendant has received no treatment and/or medication for his condition at the institution and offered bail conditions which could be imposed. AUSA Lopez-Rocafort argued against bail. Arguments heard from both parties. After hearing all arguments, the Court reaffirmed its prior decision of detention without bail, but expressed concern as to defendant's medical condition. The Court urged Mr. Garay to follow administrative procedures for MDC and contact the institution's legal counsel, Mr. Matos, in order to get feedback as to what treatment  and/or medication and/or course of action was being taken as to defendant. If no feedback is received within ten days, Mr. Garay is to inform the Court. AUSA Lopez- Rocafort asked that he be copied of the communication sent to MDC's legal counsel, so that they can also aid in obtaining the information and/or treatment for defendant, if defendant didn't have any objection to the same. Defendant will remain under custody pending trial. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 02:19.Hearing ended at 02:42. Interpreter -Sonia Crescioni. (yr) (Entered: 11/20/2015)

ORDER denying 764 Motion to Restrict as to Pedro Vigio-Aponte (2); re 765 Motion for Discovery as to Pedro Vigio-Aponte (2). Movant is requesting discovery against the Probation Department of this Court, not the government. Rule 16 and Kyles do not stand for that proposition. However, the Court will verify Calvino's PSR and will make certain that the government's discovery is in line with what Probation had by way of criminal history at the time of the PSR was prepared. Taking this a step further, Probation has confirmed they only have the arrest warrants and the local charge (denuncia). There are no sworn statements. Signed by Judge Jose A. Fuste on 12/07/2015. (dv) (Entered: 12/07/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment/Bail as to William Ortiz-Aguirre (16) Counts 1,2,3 held on 2/2/2016. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez, Atty. Ernesto Hernandez and PO Linda Perez.  Defendant was present in court and assisted by court interpreter Heidi Cazes. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. Unless there is an order or directive from the presiding US District Judge indicating otherwise, the government shall have 7 days to produce discovery and the defense 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Fuste for further proceedings. As to bail, defense counsel had no evidence to rebut the presumption. The government requested detention. The Court ordered defendant detained on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 09:15. Hearing held at 09:56.Hearing ended at 09:59. (ft) (Entered: 02/04/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Bail as to Felix A. Malave-Torres (52) Count 1,2,3 held on 4/8/2016. Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Marta Rey-Cacho. The defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts of the Indictment. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Jose A. Fuste for further proceedings. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Arraignment/Bail as to Rafael Ojeda-Andino (21) Counts 1,2,3 held on 4/19/2016. Present: AUSA Glenn Goetchius, Atty. Humberto Guzman, and USPO Emanuel Bravo. Defendant is under custody, present in court, and assisted by the court interpreters. Atty. Guzman clarified that defendant's true name is Rafael Ojeda-Andino. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to counts 1-3. The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Jose A. Fuste for further proceedings. As to detention, defense counsel had no evidence to rebut the presumption, but reserved the right to request a reopening of the bail hearing. The Court ordered defendant detained on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. Order to issue. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 10:00. Hearing held at 11:09. Hearing ended at 11:12. Interpreter Heidi Cazes and Annie Flores. (ari) (Entered: 04/20/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno- Coll:Case called for Change of Plea as to Rafael Ojeda-Andino (21) but not held on 5/20/2016. Present were AUSA Marie Christine Amy and defense counsel Humberto Guzman. The defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Defense counsel Guzman informed the Court that his client did not want to go forth with the plea agreement at this time. He also requested to withdraw as attorney for defendant. After hearing defendant's allegations, as well as those of defense counsel Guzman, the Court found that there was no evidence of ineffective counsel assistance but that there was a breakdown in the attorney-client relationship based on lack of trust from the part of the defendant. Therefore, the Court granted defense counsel's oral motion to withdraw and new counsel shall be appointed. Case is referred back to the presiding judge for further proceedings. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 11:00 am. Hearing held at 11:15 am. Hearing ended at 11:43 am. Interpreter Sonia Crescion1. (cmd) (Entered: 05/26/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Francisco A. Besosa: Sentencing held on 7/12/2016 for Pedro Vigio-Aponte (2). Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez and Atty. Anita Hill. USPO Deni Rodriguez also present. Defendant U/C, present in court and assisted by the certified court interpreter. Defendant stated that he did not wish to make an allocution. Counts 1, 2, 3, 6 and 7, IMPR.: As to Count 1, for the remainder of his natural life. As to Count 2, One Hundred Twenty (120) months to be served concurrently with the sentence as to Count 1. As to Count 3, Three Hundred (300) months to be served consecutively to the sentences as to Count 1 and Count 2. As to Count 6, for the remainder of his natural life. As to Count 7, Three Hundred (300) months to be served consecutively to the sentences imposed in Counts 1, 2, 3, and 6; SRT: Five (5) years as to each Counts 1, 2, 3, 6 and 7 to be served concurrently with each other; No fine imposed; SMA: $500.00 ($100 as to each Counts 1, 2, 3, 6 and 7). All other terms and conditions will be set in the judgment. (Court Reporter Joe Reynosa.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 09:27.Hearing ended at 10:05. Interpreter Janis Palma. (grf) (Entered: 07/12/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Pedro A. Delgado- Hernandez:Sentencing Hearing as to Luis Martinez-Nieves (45) was called on 7/19/2016 but not held. Present: AUSA Ginette Milanes (for Victor Acevedo), Attorney Juan Albino-Gonzalez and USPO Rodriguez. The defendant was present in court U/C and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Attorney Albino-Gonzalez argued the issue of relevant conduct and the effect on the sentencing guideline. The Court ordered attorney Albino- Gonzalez to file a supplement to the sentencing memorandum specifically referencing the issue of relevant conduct. Attorney Albino-Gonzalez requested 45 days to file the supplement due to calendar conflict. The Court continued the sentencing hearing set for today in order to provide defense counsel the opportunity to submit the supplement and for the Court to review it. Defendant's Supplement to the Sentencing Memorandum due by 9/1/2016. Sentencing Hearing CONTINUED for 9/16/2016 10:00 AM in Courtroom 3 before Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez. The Court ordered that the defendant remain in MDC pending sentencing. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 09:30.Hearing ended at 10:18.Interpreter Heidi Cazes. (cc) (Entered: 07/19/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 7/22/2016 for William Ortiz-Aguirre (16). AUSA Marie Christine Amy and defense counsel Ernesto Hernandez-Milan were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. No objections to the PSI Report. Counsel argued for a variance for a lower imprisonment term. The Government recommended that the Court sentence defendant to the middle range of the sentencing guideline. After  listening to the parties, the Court granted a variance below the guideline. Defendant's allocution was heard. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1 and 3, Impr Term: Ninety-six (96) as to Count One and Sixty (60) months as to Count Three to be served consecutively with each other for a total imprisonment term of One hundred fifty-six (156) months. SRT: Five (5) years as to Counts One and Three to be served concurrently with each other. SMA: $100.00 per count for a total assessment of $200.00. Per request of the Government, Count(s) 2, is Dismissed. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Carolina Aparicio.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 03:00. Hearing held at 03:52. Hearing ended at 04:20. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (br) (Entered: 08/03/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Francisco A. Besosa: Sentencing held on 8/18/2016 for Daniel O. Martinez-Velez (77). Present: AUSA Max Perez-Bouret and Atty. Ignacio Fernandez. USPO Ariel Rivera also present. Defendant U/C, present in court and assisted by the certified court interpreter. During his allocution, defendant expressed his reasons as to why he was not satisfied with defense counsel's representation. The Court heard his allocution and informed defendant that if after being sentenced, he still believed that he was not well represented, he could file a motion as to the matter. Counts 1, 3, IMPR.: Thirty-four (34) months and Ten (10) days as to Count 1 and Sixty (60) months as to Count 3, to be served consecutively to each other, for a total imprisonment term of Ninety-Four (94) months and Ten (10) days. The Court applied a credit, as to Count 1, of Thirteen (13) months and Twenty (20) days for the time spent in state custody for relevant conduct. SRT: Five (5) years as to Count 1 and Five (5) years as to Count 3, to be served concurrently with each other; No fine imposed; SMA: $200.00; Count 2, Dismissed. All other terms and conditions shall be set in the judgment. (Court Reporter Joe Reynosa.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 09:34.Hearing ended at 09:54. Interpreter Edna Brayfield. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Change of Plea Hearing as to Felix Rodriguez-Rodriguez (76) held on 9/26/2016. Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo and defense counsel Thomas Trebilcock. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant was found competent to plea. He was advised of the maximum penalties he is facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving his constitutional rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Jay A. Garcia Gregory, U.S. District Judge so that the guilty plea as to count one (1) and three (3) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. Sentencing Hearing is set for 1/20/2016 at 2:00 PM in Courtroom 6 before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 9:30 am. Hearing held at 10:04 am. Hearing ended at 10:30 am. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (cmd) (Entered: 09/28/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Sentencing held on 9/26/2016 for Nilda Santiago-Espinosa (93). AUSA Marie Christine Amy and defense counsel Luz M. Rios were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The government requested a sentence at the middle range while defense requested a lower end of the guidelines. No objections to the PSI Report. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1, Impr Term: 57 months (time served to be credited). SRT: 3 years. SMA: $100.00. Per request of the government, Count(s) 2 and 4 are Dismissed. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Brenda Davila.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 03:30. Hearing held at 04:01. Hearing ended at 04:18. Interpreter Enith Valdez. (br) (Entered: 10/06/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin:Arraignment/Bail as to Jaame M. Semiday-Perez (48) Counts 1-3 held on 11/1/2016. Present: AUSA Maritza Gonzalez, Atty. Maria Dominguez, and USPO August Castro. Defendant is under custody, present in court, and assisted by the court interpreter. Defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings. He waived the reading of the indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to counts 1-3. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Jay A. Garcia Gregory for trial setting. As to bail, defense counsel informed that they had nothing to offer, but reserved the right to reopen the hearing. The Court ordered defendant detained without bail on the basis of danger to the community and risk of flight. Order to issue. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 09:00. Hearing held at 09:33. Hearing ended at 09:37. Interpreter Edna Brayfield. (ari) (Entered: 11/07/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Change of Plea Hearing as to Kernis Rodriguez-Rivera (62) held on 11/2/2016. Present were AUSA John Mathews and Mr. Francisco Acevedo-Padilla. Defendant was present and under custody. Waiver of JT and consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant is found competent at this time to understand the proceedings. Defendant is advised of the maximum penalties he's facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving said rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Judge Garcia so that the guilty plea as to counts One (1) and Three (3) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. Defendant will remain under custody. Sentencing Hearing set for 3/2/2017 at 02:30 PM in Courtroom 6 before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory. Amy) and defense counsel Thomas Trebilcock were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The government stands by the plea agreement. No objections to the PSI Report. Defendant's allocution was heard. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1, 3, Impr Term: 18 months as to Count One and 60 months as to Count Three to be served consecutively for a total term of imprisonment of 78 months. SRT: 3 years as to Count One and 5 years as to Count Three to be served concurrently with each other. SMA: $100 per count for a total of $200.00. Per request of the government, Count(s) 2, is Dismissed. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Milva Razetto.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 03:10. Hearing ended at 03:31. Interpreter Heidi Cazes. (br) (Entered: 01/25/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Arraignment/Bail as to Frankie Rosa-Calderon (3) Count 1,2,3 held on 3/16/2017. Present were AUSA Marie Christine Amy and Mr. Edgar Sanchez. Defendant was present and under custody. He was found competent at this time to understand the proceedings. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for scheduling. As to bail, Mr. Sanchez argued as to bail and offered conditions of release, including a third party custodian. The Government argued for detention. After hearing both parties, the Court ordered defendant detained without bail. Order to issue. ORDER striking 2595 Motion Requesting Order as to Amaury Mendez-Rosado (42); striking 2909 Supplemental Motion as to Amaury Mendez-Rosado (42). Defendant's pro se status does not insulate him from complying with this Court's procedural rules. Ahmed v. Rosenblatt, 118 F.3d 886, 890 (1st Cir. 1997). In this district, all documents must be filed in English or accompanied by a certified English translation, as required by 48 U.S.C.  864 ("[a]ll pleadings and proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico shall be conducted in the English language") and Local Criminal Rule 112, which provides that motion practice in criminal cases shall be subject to Local Civil Rule 5(g) ("[a]ll documents not in the English language which are presented or filed, whether as evidence or otherwise, must be accompanied by a certified translation into English prepared by an interpreter certified by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts"). Defendant may refile these motions in the English language. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 4/18/2017. (MQ) (Entered: 04/18/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 5/25/2017 for Hector J. Cruz- Vargas (99). AUSA Victor Acevedo and defense counsel Francisco Acevedo were present. Defendant was present, on bond and assisted by a certified court interpreter. No objections to the PSI Report. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. The government stands by the plea, but has no objection to a sentence of 60 months. The Court sentenced defendant under a variance. Sentence imposed as to Count(s) 1 and 3, IMPR: Time Served as to Count One and Sixty (60) months as to Count Three to be served consecutively to each other for a total of Sixty (60) months of imprisonment. SRT: Five (5) years as to each count to be served concurrently with each other. SMA: $100.00 per count for a total of $200.00. Per request of the government Count(s) 2, is Dismissed. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Counsel informed that defendant no intention to appeal the sentence imposed. ORDER striking: 3341 Notice (Other), filed by Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho (71), 2954 Notice (Other) filed by Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho (71), 2929 Motion for Setting filed by Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho(71), 2949 Notice (Other) filed by Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho (71), 2929 MOTION for Setting filed by Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho (71). In this district, all documents must be filed in English or accompanied by a certified English translation, as required by 48 U.S.C.  864 ("[a]ll pleadings and proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico shall be conducted in the English language"). Thus, if Defendant wishes the Court to consider any request, he must file a motion in English or accompanied by a certified English translation. Furthermore, since Defendant is represented by counsel, any motions should be filed by Defendant's counsel. Counsel for Defendant is hereby ORDERED to confer with his client regarding the requests contained in these letters and file a motion accordingly, if needed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia- Gregory on 9/14/2017. (MQ) (s/c to deft) (su). (Entered: 09/14/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Sentencing held on February 13, 2018 for Carlos Velazquez-Fontanez (66). Present were AUSA Victor O. Acevedo-Hernandez, and court appointed counsel Victor M. Chico-Luna. The defendant was present in court, under the custody of the U.S. Marshals and was assisted by certified interpreter. This defendant was found guilty by a jury on November 9, 2016 as to Counts 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Counsel for the defendant proceeded to provide relevant mitigating circumstances to be considered by the Court, and requested a downward variance. The United States requested that defendant's request for a downward variance be denied and be sentenced to a life imprisonment. Defendant's allocution heard. The Court after having heard the parties, and prior of imposing sentencing stated for the record the factors outline in 18 U.S.C.  3553(a) and imposed a sentence otherwise outside the sentencing guideline and request for a downward variance by the defendant was granted. Imprisonment of 120 months as to counts 1, 2, and 4 to be served concurrently with each other; 60 months as to count 3, and 300 months as to count 5 to be served consecutively with each other and to be served consecutively with the 120 months imposed in counts 1, 2, and 4, for a total of 480 months. Supervised Release Term of 10 years as to counts 1, and 2, and 5 years as to counts 3, 4, and 5 to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $500.00. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised as to his right to appeal after a guilty verdict by a jury. Time served will given for time served in connection with the offenses for which sentence has been imposed. (Court Reporter Diana Breaz, Interpreter Thomas Kavelin, USPO Carolina Aparicio.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:27.Hearing ended at 05:19. (om) (Entered: 02/15/2018)

JUDGMENT as to Carlos Velazquez-Fontanez (66), Counts 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 120 months as to counts 1, 2, and 4 to be served concurrently with each other; 60 months as to count 3, and 300 months as to count 5 to be served consecutively with each other and to be served consecutively with the 120 months imposed in counts 1, 2, and 4, for a total of 480 months. Supervised Release term of 10 years as to counts 1, and 2, and 5 years as to counts 3, 4, and 5 to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $500.00. Signed by Judge Jay A. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 3/14/2018 for Ezier Clemente-Lamb (44). Present were AUSA Kelly Zenon for Alberto Lopez-Rocafort, defense counsel Leonardo Aldridge and USPO Deni Rodriguez. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defense counsel informed that defendant was diagnosed with Crohns Disease and requires special medical treatment. Changes to PSR are to be made. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendants allocution was heard. Imprisonment for a tern of 60 months as to count 1 and 60 months as to count 3, to be served CONSECUTIVELY to each other for a TOTAL of 120 months. SRT of 3 years as to count 1 and 5 years as to count 3, to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $100 per count for a total of $200.00. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Defendant waived to appeal, but was advised of his right to appeal. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That he service his sentence in Devens MA. 2. That he be afforded with vocational rehabilitation training and education programs. 3. That he be provided with the 500 hours drug treatment. 4. The defendant shall be evaluated by a Psychiatrist to determine if he is in need of mental health treatment while incarcerated. 5. That he be afforded English as a Second language program. 6. That he was diagnosed with Crohns Disease and requires special medical treatment. (Court Reporter Diane Breaz.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:29.Hearing ended at 04:46.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (su) (Entered: 03/16/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno- Coll:Motion Hearing as to Frankie Rosa-Calderon (3) held on 4/11/2018 re 3530 MOTION to Appoint Counsel filed by Frankie Rosa-Calderon. Present were AUSA Sean Gajewski and defense counsel Edgar Sanchez. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. The Court inquired as to the status of the case. Attorney Sanchez stated that case 17-182-PAD is also pending and that it was his intention to request a consolidation of both cases for sentencing purposes. The presiding judges are aware of the matter. The Government did not oppose that case 17- 182-PAD be considered relevant conduct in this case and that they be consolidated for sentencing. The Court allowed the defendant to voice his concerns re the case and his legal representation. The Court, once again, explained the charges against the defendant and the plea offers tendered by the Government. Colloquy held between the Court and the defendant. After hearing the parties, the Court stated that Attorney Sanchez had been diligent and that his efforts have been in the defendant's best interest. The Court found that there is no relief to be provided. It will be within the presiding judge's discretion to accept the plea and the consolidation of the cases for sentencing purposes. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 9:30 am. Hearing held at 10:02 am. Hearing ended at
29 am. Interpreter Mayra Cardona. (cmd) Modified on 4/17/2018 to correct typo (mem). (Entered: 04/16/2018)

ORDER as to Carlos Velazquez-Fontanez (66). The Court's decision at Docket No. 3591 would also apply to co-Defendant Velazquez-Fontanez, as he was also convicted of two  924(c) counts, one predicated on the drug offense and the other predicated on a drive- by-shooting committed in furtherance of the drug conspiracy. See Docket No. 2796. Because an appeal is pending as to Velazquez-Fontanez's case, this Court is without jurisdiction to amend the judgment and sentence. Instead, pursuant to Fed. R. App. P. 12.1, the Court notes that it would grant a motion to dismiss one of the  924(c) convictions as to Velazquez-Fontanez. See Fed. R. App. P. 12.1 ("Ifa timely motion is made in the district court for relief that it lacks authority to grant because of an appeal that has been docketed and is pending, the movant must promptly notify the circuit clerk if the district court states either that it would grant the motion or that the motion raises a substantial issue."). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 5/10/2018. (MQ) (Entered: 05/10/2018)

Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo- Hernandez, defense counsel Jose Agustin Arce-Diaz and USPO Eddebbie Cofresi. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. NO objection to PSR. Defendants allocution heard. Defendant was sentence for imprisonment for a term of (63) months as to count | and (60) months as to count 3, to be served CONSECUTIVELY to each other for a TOTAL of (123) MONTHS. SRT of (5) years as to count | and (3) years as to count 3, to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $200.00. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That he service his sentence in Ft Dix, New Jersey. 2. That he be afforded with vocational rehabilitation training and education programs. 3. That he be provided with the 500 hours drug treatment. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (Court Reporter Diane Breaz.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 05:19.Hearing ended at 05:35 Interpreter Carlos Lao. (su) (Entered: 06/08/2018)

SRT of (5) years as to count | and (3) years as to count 3, to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $200.00. Count(s) 2, Dismissed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Status Conference as to Edgardo R. Ruano-Chevere (70), Kevin Castro-Vega (87) held on 6/7/2018. Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo, Carmen Soto and Jose Perez-Ortiz. Counsel Carmen Soto on behalf of defendant Kevin Castro- Vega (87), requested additional time to continue plea negotiation. Request granted. Counsel Jose Perez-Ortiz on behalf of defendant Edgardo R. Ruano-Chevere (70) informed that he is currently reviewing Mr. Ruano's medical records from his hospitalizations in Puerto Rico and that he recently requested the medical records from Institutions in New York, were his client Edgardo R. Ruano-Chevere received additional treatment. The purpose of reviewing the medical records is to understand Mr. Ruano's physical limitations and provide a timeline of his multiple hospitalizations. The Court GRANTED the 3610 MOTION Requesting Review Pretrial Report and expected that those medical record from Institutions in New York, arrive here before the next Status Conference. Change of Plea due by 8/13/2018. Further Status Conference set for 8/16/2018 03:00 PM in Courtroom 6 before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory. The Court made a finding that the Speedy Trial remains tolled in the interest of justice which outweighs the best interest of the public and the defendants under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 3161(h)(7)(A) until the next conference.(Court Reporter Diane Breaz.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 03:51.Hearing ended at 03:58. (su) (Entered: 06/12/2018)

Certified Copy of Order from USCA as to Carlos Velazquez-Fontanez (66) entered on 08/07/18 re: 3479 Notice of Appeal - Final Judgment; Appellant Carlos Velazquez- Fontanez has filed an "informative motion requesting stay of proceedings pending district court's resolution." He asks that the court stay this appeal and remand the case so that the district court can consider whether to dismiss one of his 18 U.S.C.  924(c) convictions, the district court having chosen that course in the case of a co-defendant and having signaled a willingness to do the same in this case. The court expresses no opinion at this time as to the propriety of the district court's stated intention to vacate one of Velazquez-Fontanez's convictions. In accordance with the foregoing, this appeal is STAYED, and the matter is REMANDED to the district court for further proceedings consistent with this order. (xi) (Entered: 08/07/2018)

Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez and defense counsel Jose G. Perez-Ortiz. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by a Certified Court Interpreter. Consent to proceed before a U.S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant was found competent to plea. He was advised of the maximum penalties he is facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving his constitutional rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Jay A. Garcia Gregory, U.S. District Judge so that the guilty plea as to counts one (1) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. The defendant will remain detained pending Sentence. Sentencing Hearing set for 12/13/2018 03:00 PM in Courtroom 6 before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory. ORDER striking 3726 Motion Requesting Order as to Francisco J. Gonzalez-Camacho (71). In this district, all documents must be filed in English or accompanied by a certified English translation, as required by 48 U.S.C.  864 ("All pleadings and proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico shall be conducted in the English language.") and Local Criminal Rule 112, which provides that motion practice in criminal cases shall be subject to Local Civil Rule 5(g) ("All documents not in the English language which are presented or filed, whether as evidence or otherwise, must be accompanied by a certified translation into English prepared by an interpreter certified by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts."). Moreover, as Defendant is represented by counsel, he should communicate with his attorney to receive status updates. In light of the numerous pro se motions filed by Defendant inquiring about the status of his case and claiming he has received no updates from counsel, see Docket No. 3491, Counsel is hereby ORDERED to periodically confer with Defendant, so Defendant is kept apprised of the status of his case. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/6/2018. (MQ) (Entered: 09/06/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 10/2/2018 for Luis E. Espada-Colon (104). Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo- Hernandez, Defense Counsel Miguel Rodriguez-Robles for Ovidio Zayas and USPO Ariana Guzman. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant accepted in open court that counsel Ovidio Zayas be substituted by counsel Miguel Rodriguez-Robles. No objections to PSR. Defendants allocution heard. Defendant was sentence for a term of imprisonment of (66) MONTHS as to Count One in Criminal Case 15-462 (104)(JAG) to be served CONSECUTIVELY to (60) MONTHS as to Count Four in Criminal Case 16-550 (1)JAG), for a TOTAL of (126) MONTHS of imprisonment. SRT of (3) years as to Count One in Cr 15-462 (104) (JAG) and (5) years as to Count Four in Cr 16-550(1)(JAG), which shall run concurrently with each. SMA of $100 as to each count. Defendant waived to appeal, but was advised of his right to appeal. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed in Cr 15-462 (JAG). Request granted. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated to Coleman, Florida, his father live in the state of Florida. 2. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program. 3. That defendant be enrolled in a substance abuse treatment program. (Court Reporter Donna Goree.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 03:44.Hearing ended at 04:02.Interpreter Annie Flores. (su) (Entered: 10/02/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 10/17/2018 for Luis Yanyore-Pizarro (43), Count(s) 1: Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez-Rocafort, Defense Counsel Carlos Beck and USPO Natalia Matos. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard by both parties. Defense counsel requested that PSR be amended to reflect that Criminal History Category is 1. Request granted. Defendants allocution was heard. Court entered a variance. The defendant was sentenced to (120) months to be served CONCURRENTLY with the sentence imposed at the federal level in Cr. 13-694(3)(DRD) and CONCURRENTLY to the sentences imposed at the state level in criminal case numbers AVI2011G0067, AVI2011G0068 and ABD2011G554. All above mentioned cases are to be considered relevant conduct as to the instant offense. Further, that pursuant to section 5G1.3(b)(1) of the U.S.S.G. defendant shall be credited a total of 85 months and 19 days. Which is the time already served since the date of his first arrest on 8/28/2011. Remaining a sentence to serve in this case of 34 MONTHS and 11 DAYS. SRT of 5 years to be served CONCURRENTLY with SRT in Cr.13-694(3)(DRD) and SMA of $100.00. Defendant waived to appeal but was advised of his right to appeal. The Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated to Mariana, FL, FCI Otisville, NY or FCI Greenville. 2. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program.3. The defendant shall be evaluated by a Psychiatrist to determine if he needs mental health treatment while incarcerated. (Court Reporter Donna Goree.)Hearing set for 02:30.Hearing held at 04:42.Hearing ended at 05:28. Interpreter Heidi Cazes. (su) Modified on 10/24/2018 (su). (Entered: 10/24/2018)

All above mentioned cases are to be considered relevant conduct as to the instant offense. Further, that pursuant to section 5G1.3(b)(1) of the U.S.S.G. defendant shall be credited a total of 85 months and 19 days. Which is the time already served since the date of his first  arrest on 8/28/2011. Remaining a sentence to serve in this case of 34 MONTHS and 11 DAYS. SRT of 5 years to be served CONCURRENTLY with SRT in Cr.13-694(3) (DRD) and SMA of $100.00. Count(s) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, Dismissed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 10/17/18.(su) (Entered: 10/24/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 11/7/2018 for Alexis Cartagena-Gerena (28). Present were AUSA Vanessa Bonano (for Victor Acevedo), defense counsel Michael Corona, and USPO Eddebbie Cofresi. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. The Court imposed sentence as to Counts 1 and 3 as follows: IMPR: 60 months as to Count 1 and 60 months as to Count 3, to be served consecutively to each other, for a total term of imprisonment of 120 months; SRT: 3 years as to Count | and 5 years as to Count 3, to be served concurrently with each other, for a total term of supervised release of 5 years; SMA: $200.00. Fine waived. Defendant waived to appeal, but was advised of his right to appeal. Government requested that remaining count be dismissed. Request granted. PSR is to be amended to correct the defendant's age and date of birth. (Court Reporter Donna Goree.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:09.Hearing ended at 04:32.Interpreter Olga Uribe. (lod) (Entered: 11/13/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 11/29/2018 for Oscar A. Calvino-Acevedo (30), Count(s) 1.Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez-Rocafort, Defense Counsel Mariangela Tirado, and USPO Milva Razetto. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Court entered a variance. Defendants allocution was heard. The defendant was sentenced to 120 months of imprisonment, to be served CONCURRENTLY with to the sentence imposed in Cr. No. 13-391(JAF). (Pursuant to U.S.S.C. 5G1.3(g)(1) defendant shall be credited since theday of this arrest on 7/6/13 to the present, for a total of 65 months and 21 days); SRT of 5 years and SMA of $100.00. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Defendant waived to appeal but was advised of his right to appeal. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated to FCI Otisville, NY. (But that he remains in MDC-Guaynabo, while the final designation is made.) 2. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program. 3. That he be provided with the 500 hours drug treatment. 4. The defendant shall be evaluated by a Psychiatrist to determine if he needs mental health treatment while incarcerated. (Court Reporter Donna Goree.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:58.Hearing ended at 05:51 Interpreter Olga Uribe. (su) (Entered: 11/30/2018)

JUDGMENT as to Oscar A. Calvino-Acevedo (30), Count(s) 1, Imprisonment for a term of to 120 months of imprisonment, to be served CONCURRENTLY with to the sentence imposed in Cr. No. 13-391(JAF). SRT of five (5) years. SMA of $100.00. Count(s) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, Dismissed. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 11/29/18.(su) Modified on 12/3/2018 to edit docket text (mem). ORDER denying 3611 Motion to Clarify as to Jose D. Resto-Figueroa (60). The government argues that the mandatory minimum sentence for Count Nine is ten years pursuant to 18 U.S.C.  924(c)(1)(A)(ili), which increases the minimum sentence "if the firearm is discharged." However, the Supreme Court has held that, because " [mJandatory minimum sentences increase the penalty for a crime... any fact that increases the mandatory minimum is an 'element' [of the crime] that must be submitted to the jury." Alleyne v. United States, 570 U.S. 99, 103 (2013). A finding that the firearm was discharged would increase the mandatory minimum for Count Nine. Thus, because the issue was not submitted to the jury, see Docket No. 2796, the Court finds that the mandatory minimum sentence for Count Nine is five years pursuant to  924(c)(1)(A) (i). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 12/7/2018. (MQ) (Entered: 12/07/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Re-sentencing as to Carlos Velazquez-Fontanez (66) held on 12/7/2018. Present were AUSA Victor Acevedo, Defense Counsel Victor Chico-Luna and USPO Malissa Aponte. The defendant was present in court, under the custody of the U.S. Marshals and was assisted by certified interpreter. This defendant was found guilty by a jury on November 9, 2016 as to Counts 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Pursuant to 3592 Order and 3883 Opinion and Order entered dismissing count 3. The case was called for Re-Sentencing. Counsel for the defendant proceeded to provide relevant mitigating circumstances to be considered by  the Court, and requested a downward variance. The United States requested that defendant's request for a downward variance be denied and be sentenced to a life imprisonment. Thereafter an Order with Statement of Reason was read by the Court. Defendant's allocution heard. The Court after having heard the parties, and prior of imposing sentencing stated for the record the factors outline in 18 U.S.C.  3553(a) and imposed a sentence otherwise outside the sentencing guideline and request for a downward variance by the defendant was granted. Defendant was sentence to 240 months of imprisonment as to counts one, two and four to be served concurrently with each other to be follow by a CONSECUTIVE term of 60 months as to count five, for a TOTAL of 300 MONTHS. SRT of 15 years as to count two and 5 years as to counts one, four and five, to be served concurrently with each other. SMA of $400.00. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised as to his right to appeal after a guilty verdict by a jury. Time served will given for time served in connection with the offenses for which sentence has been imposed. Objections was heard by the government. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Recommendation to the BOP: 1. That defendant be designated in the state of Coleman, his family live nearby. 2. That defendant be enrolled in an educational/vocational rehabilitation training program. 3. That he be provided with the 500 hours drug treatment. (Court Reporter Donna Goree.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:33.Hearing ended at 05:05.Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. (su) (Entered: 12/11/2018)

COPY OF ORDER denying | Motion to Vacate, for the reasons stated in the government's Opposition, Docket No. 20. Specifically, Petitioner's claim that he was unaware of the possibility of a consecutive sentence is conclusively refuted by the record. The Plea Agreement repeatedly stated that the Court was not bound by the agreement, and that the government would recommend a consecutive sentence. Docket

2 at 3-5. Then, at the Change of Plea Hearing, the Court reiterated this before Petitioner responded that he understood the implications of his guilty plea and that he still wished to enter such a plea. Docket No. 20 at 7-8. Moreover, Petitioner's claim that his trial counsel was ineffective for failing to file a notice of appeal likewise fails. Despite the waiver clause in the Plea Agreement, Petitioner instructed his trial counsel to appeal based on his belief that the consecutive sentence imposed was unreasonable. However, because Petitioner had ample notice of the possibility of a consecutive sentence before knowingly and voluntarily pleading guilty, the basis for such an appeal would have been meritless. See United States v. Pacheco, 921 F.3d 1, 2 (1st Cir. 2019) ("A waiver of appellate rights is enforceable provided that, among other things, the defendant enter[ed] into the waiver knowingly and voluntarily.") (quotation marks and citation omitted). Thus, counsel's failure to appeal cannot constitute ineffective assistance of counsel. See Acha v. United States, 910 F.2d 28, 32 (1st Cir. 1990) (stating that attorneys are "under no obligation to raise meritless claims [and] [fJailure to do so does not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel."). Finally, the Court rejects Petitioner's double jeopardy claim because there is insufficient evidence on the record to show either that the two criminal cases involved identical offenses, or even that both cases dealt with the same act or transaction. For these reasons, the Court denies Petitioner's ineffective assistance of counsel claim because it cannot find that counsel's choices were "so patently unreasonable that no competent attorney would have made [them]." United States v. Rodriguez, 675 F.3d 48, 56 (1st Cir. 2012) (citation omitted). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/3/2019. (MQ) (Entered: 09/03/2019). ORDER as to Luis F. Alicea-Colon (4) re 2042 Motion to Vacate (2255), filed by Luis F. Alicea-Colon. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/3/19. 16 cv 2420 (JAG). (mg) (Entered: 11/09/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Further Status Conference as to Angel L. Soto-Ramos (29) held on October 4, 2019. Present AUSA Maria L. Montanez for AUSA Alberto R. Lopez, and Jose R. Wiscovitch for retained counsel Edwin Prado Galarza. As previously stated, discovery was provided. Plea offer tendered as well. Proffer's meeting held. The defense made a counter offer which is in the process to be reviewed by the United States. Hence, a further period of thirty (30) days requested to finalize plea negotiations. The request was granted. The Court set the following deadlines. Change of plea motion shall be filed on or before November 4, 2019. If change of plea motion is not filed, a Further Status Conference set for November 8, 2019 at 3:00 PM to be held at the Old San Juan Courthouse. The Court made a finding that the ends of justice is served by granting defendant's request for more time to finalize the good faith plea negotiations in this case which outweigh the best interest of the public and the defendant in a speedy trial. (Court Reporter Rachelle M. Robinson-Ware.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 03:45.Hearing ended at 03:47. (om) (Entered: 10/07/2019)

Miunute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Reynaldo Gonzalez-Zayas (83) held on 10/11/2019 in Cr. Nos. 15-462 (JAG) and 12-062 (GAG). Present: AUSA Vanessa Bonhomme, AFPD Yasmin Irizarry, USPO Jeffrey Semidey. Defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Counsel for defendant informed that they are waiving the hearing. Waiver of Preliminary Hearing was filed. The Court approved the same and made a finding of probable cause as to the allegations contained in the motion filed at Docket No. 110 in Cr. 12-062 (GAG) and Docket No. 4025 Cr. 15-462 (JAG). Both cases are referred to the presiding judges for setting of a final revocation hearing. As to detention, defense counsel argued in favor of releasing the defendant into the Hogares Crea drug treatment program. Government moved for detention. The Court ordered the defendant released under the same conditions of release with the added condition of inpatient drug treatment to be coordinated by the USPO, as well as drug testing. The U.S. Marshal Service will transport the defendant back to the courthouse on Tuesday 10/15/2019 for his release. Defense counsel informed that a motion to consolidate both cases will be filed and requests that the final revocation hearing not be held for at least three months in order to allow the defendant to receive treatment. (Court Reporter DCR/ Courtroom 9.) Hearing set for 09:00. Hearing held at 09:49. Hearing ended at 09:55. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (bgl) (Entered: 10/11/2019)

COPY OF ORDER denying 2983 Motion to Vacate (2255) as to Jesus De Jesus-Colon (31) filed in 17-cv-1195-JAG denying Petitioner's Pro Se 1 Motion to Vacate, Set Aside or Correct Sentence under 28 U.S.C.  2255, for the reasons stated in the Government's 11 Opposition thereto. Specifically, Petitioner's ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim and the grounds provided in support thereof are refuted by the record, so Petitioner has failed to show that his attorney's performance was deficient; and/or that there is a reasonable probability that, but for his attorney's unprofessional errors, the proceedings would have yielded a different result. See Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 669 (1984). Moreover, Petitioner's offense of conviction for Count Three did not involve a crime of violence (rather, possession of a firearm in furtherance of a drug trafficking crime); and Petitioner was not sentenced under (or subject to) the Armed Career Criminal Act, 18 U.S.C.  924(e), or the Career Offender Guideline, U.S.S.G.  4B1.1, so Johnson is inapplicable to the instant case. See Muoz-Rivera v. United States, Case No. 16-CV-2308, 2019 WL 4784895, at *3 (D.P.R. Sep. 30, 2019) (finding Johnson inapplicable to sentences resting upon  924(c)(1)(A) when these pertain to the use of a firearm during and in relation to a drug trafficking crime). Finally, the Court ORDERS that no certificate of appealability should be issued in the event that Petitioner files a notice of appeal because there is no substantial showing of a denial of a constitutional right under 28 U.S.C.  2253(c)(2). Petitioner's 18 Motion to Appoint Counsel for these proceedings is now moot. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 1/29/2020. (mcm) Civil Case 3:17-cv-01195-JAG closed. (Entered: 01/30/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice 4168 Motion for Release from Custody as to Orlando J. Santana (39). Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release 1s warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to show (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies and (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence. Defendant's motion lacks specific information regarding: (a) the risk of COVID-19 infection at the facility where he is currently being held; or (b) any preexisting health condition that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. Finally, the BOP has implemented a comprehensive plan to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission and protect the well-being of all inmates. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion for Early Release is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 5/28/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 05/28/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice 4151 Motion for Release from Custody as to Kelvin D. Morales-Cintron (10); granting 4178 Motion to Restrict as to Kelvin D. Morales- Cintron (10); noted 4179 Motion in Compliance as to Kelvin D. Morales-Cintron (10). Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even assuming, without deciding, that the Court may excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information or evidence regarding the risk of COVID-19 infection at the facility where he is currently being held, and evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population, especially considering that Defendant's allegations about his health conditions are contradicted by the PSR. Moreover, the BOP has implemented a comprehensive plan to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission and protect the well-being of all inmates. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/11/2020. (MQ) (Entered: 06/11/2020)

ORDER denying 4218 Motion Requesting Order as to Walter D. Muller-Colon (63). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information and evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Defendant alleges that he suffers from respiratory issues but the medical records submitted show a single instance of pneumonia in September 2017. The record contains no evidence of respiratory issues after this date--the physician's note submitted is based on a review of Defendant's 2017 medical records, not on a recent medical examination. Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering his drug and firearm convictions; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmates place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C.  3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 10/14/2020. (MQ) Modified on 10/14/2020 to edit docket text as per Chamber's request. (mg). (Entered: 10/14/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Sentencing held on 10/27/2020 for Angel L. Soto-Ramos (29). Present: AUSA Alberto R.Lopez- Rocafort, Defense Counsel Edwin Prado and USPO Ariel Rivera. Defendant under custody, present in court via VTC and assisted by an official court interpreter. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for this proceeding and agreed to proceed with the via VTC due to the COVID-19 emergency and pursuant to CARES Act,  15002(b)(1). Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of defendant. Government's position as to punishment heard. Defendants allocution heard. After having heard the parties, the Court imposed sentence. Defendant was sentenced 120 months; SRT of 5 years; SMA of $100.00; Fine waived. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. Government requested that remaining count(s) be dismissed. Request granted. Defendant waived to appeal but was advised of his right to appeal. (Court Reporter Rachelle Robinson.)Hearing set for 11:30.Hearing held at 12:35.Hearing ended at 01:03.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (su) (Entered: 10/28/2020)

ORDER as to Jose E. Rivera-Maldonado (58) denying without prejudice 4277 Motion to Reduce Sentence; noted 4286 Motion in Compliance. Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that a sentence reduction is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) extraordinary and  compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (2) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (3) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Defendant exhausted administrative remedies, but his motion lacks any evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). The motion similarly lacks any evidence regarding the alleged family circumstances. Defendant has also failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crimes of conviction, his prior criminal history, and his multiple disciplinary infractions while imprisoned (including assault without serious injury, possession of unauthorized items including drugs and/or alcohol, possession of hazardous tool, interfering with staff, and refusing to obey order); or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C.  3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/25/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 02/25/2021)

ORDER as to Kernis Rodriguez-Rivera (62) denying 4278 MOTION to Reduce Sentence; granting 4282 MOTION for Extension of Time to File Response/Reply; noted 4287 MOTION in Compliance. While the Supreme Court recently held that  924(c)(3) (B) is unconstitutionally vague, United States v. Davis, 139 S.Ct. 2319, 2336 (2019), Defendant's conviction does not rely on this crime of violence definition, because he was convicted of possession of a firearm in furtherance of a drug trafficking crime. As such, Davis is inapplicable. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/25/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 02/25/2021)

ORDER denying without prejudice 4298 Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Felix A. Malave-Torres (52). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C.

c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to show: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even if the Court were to excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crimes of conviction; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C.  3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 3/10/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 03/10/2021)

ORDER denying without prejudice 4284 Motion for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A) as to Rafael Ojeda-Andino (21); granting 4290 Motion to Restrict as to Rafael Ojeda-Andino (21); noted 4291 Motion in Compliance as to Rafael Ojeda- Andino (21). Defendant has failed to meet his burden of establishing that compassionate  release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (2) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (3) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Defendant's motion lacks evidence supporting the allegations of a preexisting health condition (asthma) that might increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d 594, 597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."). Moreover, FCI Talladega has already vaccinated approximately one third of the inmate population, so it seems more likely than not that Defendant will have quicker access to the vaccination while imprisoned. Defendant has similarly failed to show that he does not pose a danger to the community, considering the crimes of conviction, his leadership role, his prior criminal history, and his disciplinary infractions while imprisoned; or that a sentence reduction would be consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements, since he has only served approximately 37% of his sentence. For these reasons, Defendant's Motion is hereby DENIED without prejudice. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Finally, Defendant has failed to show that this Court has jurisdiction over any request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C.  3621(b). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 3/17/2021. (MQ) (Entered: 03/17/2021)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Change of Plea Hearing as to Kidanny Figueroa-Osorio (17) held on 6/7/2021. Present were AUSA Cristina Caraballo for Alberto Lopez and Defense Counsel Jose A. Suarez-Santa. The  defendant was under custody, assisted by a certified court interpreter and present in court. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for this proceeding and agreed to proceed with the hearing via VTC. The defendant was found competent to plea. The defendant was advised of the maximum penalties he is facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving his constitutional rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the - PLEA AGREEMENT as to Count One (1) and Three (3) of the Indictment was accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. The defendant will remain detained pending sentence. Parties' Sentencing Memorandum Filing due by 9/17/2021. Sentencing Hearing set for 10/4/2021 02:30 PM in VTC Bridge JAG before Judge Jay A.
